description.narrative: Finansiellt stöd och samarbete med The Human Rights Center vid Addis Abeba Universitet i syfte att stärka utbildning och forsking inom området mänskliga rättigheter. Samarbete mellan Raoul Wallenberg Institute (RWI) och AAU-CHR, inom CHR utbildning, juridisk hjälp och forsking
Support to the Centre for Human Rights at the Addis Abeba University and its Strategic Plan 2016-20. The support is made in collaboration with Norway.
The proposed interventions goal is to contribute to the long term goal of ensuring respect for the human rights of all Ethiopians.

description.narrative: Below is a summary of the main achievements in 2019: - Developing an interdisciplinary MA curriculum on the Rights of Children:The curriculum for MA in Children’s Rights and Childhood Studies has been finalizedaccording to the work plan. Though the curriculum is finalized, the formal process forapproval of the curriculum and the launch of the program are still pending. Note:Follow-up needed on how the process is progressing towards the final launch of theprogram.- Developing curriculum for MA program on good governance and human rights:This activity will not be implemented due to a new rule in the University that does notencourage the development of new curricula. Note: follow-up on the reallocation of thebudget line. - Training 1: Human Rights of Internally Displaced Persons- Training 2: Media Freedom and Human Rights Both the trainings have been conducted as per the workplan. The immediate resultsachieved through these trainings could be seen through training evaluationquestionnaires however changes in attitude and behaviour will take time to assess andrequired in-depth monitoring process. - Textbooks and teaching material on “Human Rights and the Administration ofCriminal Justice” and “Local Governance and Human Rights” are in the process of beenprepared. Delay in implementation has been explained in the report. - This year, CHR organized a policy dialogue forum on a theme “Confronting the Pastand Building the Future: Promises of Transitional Justice in Ethiopia”. This is a timelyand pertinent topic; the forum has been well attended and constructive/informativediscussions have been held. The actual result in change in behaviour/attitude is yet to beassessed. Note: Follow-up needed on whether the brief has been prepared and disseminated. - Organizing Networking and Experience Sharing Workshop - on legal aid in universities- done- Grant were given for three universities: Jimma, Mekelle and Debreberhan. The granthave been mostly used to provide legal aid services. The legal aid services provided asdescribed in the report have been successful in providing access to justice to vulnerablegroups. The same is true for the legal aid service provided by the legal aid centres established bythis project in 5 project areas. CHR has managed to provide free legal services to 8,033individuals. Through the services rendered by CHR, women, children, persons withdisabilities, workers, migrants and other vulnerable groups have used legal andadministrative remedies to seek redress for violations of their rights. The legal aid provision centers of CHR provide legal aid services which include advice; referral and information; preparation of statement of claim, statement of defense and memorandumof appeal; court representation; and preparation of other administrative applications andpleadings. In the reporting period, as result of services rendered (i.e. preparation of pleadings andcourt representation) by CHR, 2,209 cases were instituted before judicial body. Inaddition, CHR also prepared 1,055 administrative applications and pleadings broughtbefore local administrative bodies by beneficiaries of the legal aid provision centers.Moreover, there are several cases with successful outcomes. Some of the success storiesare provided in the narrative report. - Two CHR PhD students were sent on study tour of one month to University of Graz tobring international experiences and improve their skills. During their stay in Graz, thestudents worked on their dissertation proposal with the assistance of professors assignedby the host institution. In addition, CHR has also selected 4 PhD and 2 MA students tobe sent on similar study tour to Lund University. - CHR has hosted two international scholars from Belgium and USA as per this year’splan. These scholars taught PhD courses among other things. - One international visiting researcher from South Africa was selected and allpreparation was completed. - The CHR provided tailor-made training for officials of local government agencies inthe six sites who will facilitate the works of community rights promoters by providingforums and the necessary support and endorsement.Topics covered during the trainingwere introduction to human rights, women’s rights, children’s rights, workers’ rights andrights of persons with disabilities. - Various training to community rights promoters has been carried out during thereporting period. CHR has 139 (31 in Addis Ababa, 27 in Adama, 25 in Ambo, 14 inDebre Birhan, 18 in Hawass and 24 in Semera) community rights promoters who areactively engaging in awareness raising campaigns, preparing simple pleadings, serving aslinks between the legal aid centers and their communities and distributing promotionalmaterials to their communities. Summary of activities undertaken by community rightspromoters from December 2018 to November 2019 is provided in the narrativereport. As highlighted above, the CHR has carried out important activities as per the workplan.The reporting period has been a good year for the Centre in terms of implementation ofplanned activities. As most activities focus on training and awareness raising, it is difficultto assess the end result without carrying out a more thorough monitoring. However, theresult achieved through the legal aid service in terms of providing vulnerable groupsaccess to justice are impressive and need to be encouraged. It is assessed that the project is on the right track. It is to be noted that the good pace thatthe Centre has maintained in 2019 has been interrupted by Covid-19 (in 2020) and therewill be a need to have a no cost extension of the program. Collaboration between RWI and CHRNote:It is to be noted that the partnership between RWI and CHR has not been smooth sincethe beginning of the project. The two institutions together with Sida held a tripartitediscussion to address the underlying issues that are negatively affecting the partnership.The minutes of meeting of the discussion is hereby attached. The points that need followup are the following: - Follow up on Mid-term evaluation of the collaboration between RWI and CHR. Thecurrent mid-term evaluation has not been accepted by the CHR. It has been agreed tocarry out another mid-term evaluation by a neutral consultant and TOR for theevaluation should be agreed by all stakehoders. - Need to discuss and revisit the needs of the centre (in terms of capacity building) andelaborate on how the collaboration between the Centre and RWI could be amendedbased on the identified needs. The initially agreed upon workplan should be a livingdocument that serves as guiding document but which is subject to revision. - The narrative and financial report for 2019 for the collaboration with RWI and thecomments given by the Centre is attached in Trac.
